cmCourseInfo.description: Our place in the Universe. Phenomena we see in the sky. What we know about the Sun, the planets and comets, and the formation of the solar system – and how we know it. What makes planets suitable for life. Finding out about the nearest stars and their planets. This course is intended for students with no science or engineering background.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Sun and Its Neighbours
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: AST121H1, AST221H1. Also excluded are CIV100H1, CIV101H1, CIV102H1, any 100- or higher-series CHM/PHY courses taken previously or concurrently (with the exception of PHY100H1, PHY101H1, PHY201H1, PHY202H1, PHY205H1, PHY207H1, CHM101H1; and AP, IB, CAPE, and GCE Transfer Credits)

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online course that involves two weekly lecture sessions (Tuesday and Thursday 6:00 – 8:00 pm EST). The lecture format will rotate between live synchronous lectures, livestreaming of recorded lectures, and asynchronous lectures where lecture time is reserved for a question and answer period. All lectures will be recorded for students wishing to take the course asynchronously. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate via Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: What we know about the properties and life cycles of stars, of galaxies, and of the Universe itself – and how we know it. How astronomers develop methods for understanding phenomena that span such vast ranges in distance and time. This course is intended for students with no science or engineering background.
cmCourseInfo.title: Stars and Galaxies
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: AST121H1, AST210H1, AST221H1, AST222H1. Also excluded are CIV100H1, CIV101H1, CIV102H1 and any 100- or higher-series CHM or PHY courses taken previously or concurrently (with the exception of PHY100H1, PHY101H1, PHY201H1, PHY202H1, PHY205H1, PHY207H1, CHM101H1; and AP, IB, CAPE, and GCE Transfer Credits)

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online course that involves two weekly lecture sessions (Tuesday and Thursday 6:00 – 8:00 pm EST). The lecture format will rotate between live synchronous lectures, livestreaming of recorded lectures, and asynchronous lectures where lecture time is reserved for a question and answer period. All lectures will be recorded for students wishing to take the course asynchronously. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate via Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: Scholarly discussion of the probability that there are planets with life elsewhere in the universe, from the perspective of current ideas concerning the origin and evolution of the universe, the solar system and life. Search techniques and possibilities for interstellar travel and space colonies are discussed.
cmCourseInfo.title: Life on Other Worlds

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course, with ~2 hours of lecturing with demos and activities provided on Tuesdays and Thursdays from 6-8 pm. The presentations will be recorded to allow review and asynchronous attendance of the classes. Students will also have the opportunity via 1 hour synchronous online tutorials held approximately once per week to ask questions and get clarifications about lectures and course content. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate Ultra.
